statement:
Given a system of linear partial differential equations with analytic
coefficients $a_{j i_1, \ldots ,i_m}$ and $b_i$
$$\sum_{j, i_1,\ldots ,i_m} a_{j i_1, \ldots ,i_m} (x_1, \ldots, x_m) {\partial^{i_1 + \cdots +i_m} u_j \over \partial x_1^{i_1} \ldots \partial x_m^{i_m}} = b_i (x_1, \ldots, x_m)$$
and analytic Cauchy data specified along a noncharacteristic analytic
surface, there exists a neighborhood of the surface such that every
smooth solution of the system defined in that neighborhood is analytic.

This theorem stengthens the Cauchy-Kowalewski theorem. While the latter
theorem asserts that a unique analytic solution exists, it still allows
the possibility that there might exist non-analytic solutions.
Holmgren’s theorem asserts that this is not the case for linear systems.

It is often possible to determine the neighborhood in which Holmgren’s
theorem holds explicitly. For instance, for many hyperbolic equations,
one can show that this neighborhood can be taken to be the entire domain
of dependence of the surface along which the boundary values were
specified.
